facts.text: Matter relates to assessment years 1952-53, 1953-54 and 1954-55 of Nizam Mir Osman Ali Khan Bahadur, Ruler of Hyderabad State prior to integration with Union of India.

anchor.surface_text: The matter relates to the assessment of the income for the years 1952-53,1953-54 and 1954-55 of Nizam Mir Osman Ali Khan Bahadur, ,who was the Ruler of Hy

facts.text: Prince Muazzam Jah Bahadur is the second son of the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: We may number set out the facts giving rise to the question reproduced above Prince Muazzam Jah Bahadur is the second son of the assessee.

facts.text: Prince Muazzam Jah Bahadur married Princess Niloufer in Nice, France on November 12, 1931 according to Muslim rites.

anchor.surface_text: The Prince was married to Princess Niloufer in Nice  France  on November 12, 1931 according to Muslim rites.

facts.text: On October 8, 1949, assessee made a settlement of Rs. 30,00,000 by transferring to trust for benefit of Princess Niloufer.

facts.text: Trustees appointed under Trust Deed: assessee, Sir Sultan Ahmed, and Shavax Ardeshir Lal (nominee of Government of India).

anchor.surface_text: The assessee, Sir Sultan Ahmed and Shavax Ardeshir Lal, a numberinee of the Government of India, were the three trustees appointed under the Trust De

facts.text: On October 8, 1949, agreement entered between Government of India, assessee (settlor), and three trustees for deposit of Rs. 30,00,000 with Government of India at 1% interest free of tax.

anchor.surface_text: On the same day an agreement was entered into between the Government of India, the assessee, as the settlor of the trust, and the three trustees for

facts.text: Agreement provides Government of India to pay Rs. 1,00,000 per annum to trustees out of corpus plus interest, free of income-tax, super-tax, etc.

facts.text: Trust deed requires trustees to pay net interest and sums to make Rs. 1,00,000 per annum to Princess Niloufer free of tax until death or remarriage.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-clause  b  of the trust deed was as under To pay the net interest of the Trust Fund or the balance thereof for the time being as and when recover

facts.text: In event of divorce, trustees may continue payments to Princess if not due to her fault.

anchor.surface_text: PROVIDED THAT in the event of the said Prince divorcing the said Princess it shall be open. to the Trustees to pay the net interest of the Trust Fund

facts.text: Unhappy differences arose between Prince Muazzam Jah Bahadur and Princess Niloufer; they lived separately; no child born.

anchor.surface_text: Unhappy differences arose between Prince Muazzam Jah Bahadur and Princess Niloufer. The husband and wife companysequently started living separately

facts.text: On September 18, 1952, two documents executed: one for dissolution of marriage, opinion of trustees that divorce not due to Princess's fault.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer held Rs. 1,00,000 per year as income of assessee, liable to tax.

facts.text: ITO order affirmed by Appellate Assistant Commissioner and Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: The order of the income-tax officer was affirmed on appeal by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner as well as by the Tribunal.

facts.text: Rate of interest on Government securities at time of agreement was 3.5 to 4% per annum.

anchor.surface_text: The rate of interest prevailing at the time of the agreement on Government and gilt-edged securities was admittedly 3 1/2 to 4 per cent per annum.

facts.text: During the three years, Government paid Rs. 1,00,000 under agreement despite transfer to assessee.

concepts.unlisted_description: Provision for referring questions of law to High Court on application

anchor.surface_text: On application filed under section 66  1  of the Act the following question, along with some other questions, was referred to the High Court . Whether on the facts of the case, the sum of Rs. 1,00,000 received by the assessee from the Trustees of Princess Niloufer Trust was liable as income under the income Tax Act and if so, whether the assessee was entitled to exemption from tax of the income under the terms of the Agreement entered into with the Government of India on 8/10/1949?

concepts.interpretation: Permits a competent beneficiary to transfer their interest in the trust, subject to limitations; proviso on married women does not apply post-dissolution of marriage
concepts.unlisted_description: Transfer of beneficial interest by beneficiary

concepts.interpretation: Taxing authorities must respect true legal relation from transaction; cannot displace legal effect by substance alone

concepts.unlisted_description: Tax follows legal form and true relation of parties, not mere substance

issues.text: whether, on the facts of the case, the sum of Rs. 1,00,000/- received by the assessee from the Trustees of Princess Niloufer Trust constituted income under the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 and if so, whether the assessee was entitled to exemption from tax in respect of the income under the terms of the agreement entered into with the Government of India on October 8, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: the sum of Rs. 1,00,000/- received by the assesses from the Trustees of Princess Niloufer Trust constituted income under the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922  hereinafter referred to as the Act  and if so, whether the assesses was entitled to exemption from tax in respect of the income under the terms of the agreement entered into with the Government of India on October 8, 1949.

issues.text: Whether on the facts of the case, the sum of Rs. 1,00,000 received by the assessee from the Trustees of Princess Niloufer Trust was liable as income under the income Tax Act and if so, whether the assessee was entitled to exemption from tax of the income under the terms of the Agreement entered into with the Government of India on 8/10/1949?

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts of the case, the sum of Rs. 1,00,000 received by the assessee from the Trustees of Princess Niloufer Trust was liable as income under the income Tax Act and if so, whether the assessee was entitled to exemption from tax of the income under the terms of the Agreement entered into with the Government of India on 8/10/1949?

issues.text: whether the benefit of that exemption was restricted to Princess Niloufer or whether the assessee, who stepped into the shoes of Princess Niloufer under the deed of release, could also avail of that benefit.
whether Princess Niloufer, who was the beneficiary under the trust, could transfer her beneficial interest in favour of the assessee.

arguments.claim: exemption from payment of tax in respect of the sum of Rs. 1,00,000 received under the trust deed could be availed of by Princess Niloufer. The assessee, who was a transferee of the rights of Princess Niloufers under the trust deed, could not get the benefit of that exemption.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Manchanda on behalf of the appellant has assailed the judgment of the High Court and has contended that the exemption from payment of tax in respect of the sum of Rs. 1,00,000 received under the trust deed could be availed of by Princess Niloufer.

arguments.court_reasoning: fair reading of the agreement shows that the basic scheme of the agreement was that the payment of Rs. 1,00,000 under the agreement would be exempted from the payment of tax

arguments.claim: Normally an amount received as income is exigible to tax, and in case the assessee seeks exemption from the payment of tax in respect of that income, the onus lies upon him. The assessee has failed to discharge that onus.

anchor.surface_text: Normally an amount received as income is exigible to tax, and in case the assessee seeks exemption from the payment of tax in respect of that income, the onus lies upon him. The assessee, according to the learned counsel, has failed to discharge that onus.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: 00,000 under the agreement. The payment of Rs. 1,00,000 under the agreement and the exception in the matter of tax were linked to-ether. It would cert

arguments.court_reasoning: contention of Mr. Gupte is well founded

arguments.claim: a fair reading of the agreement dated October 8, 1949 goes to show that the benefit of exemption from payment of tax in respect of the sum of Rs. 1,00,000 was not confined to Princess Niloufer only but could also be availed of by the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: As against the above, Mr. Gupte on behalf of the assessee-respondent has contended that a fair reading of the agreement dated October 8, 1949 goes to show that the benefit of exemption from payment of tax in respect of the sum of Rs. 1,00,000 was not confined to Princess Niloufer only but could also be availed of by the assessee.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: 00,000 under the agreement. The payment of Rs. 1,00,000 under the agreement and the exception in the matter of tax were linked to-ether. It would cert

arguments.court_reasoning: we are of the opinion that the contention of Mr. Gupte is well founded

arguments.claim: the question of the grant of exemption on the payment of tax to the assessee as a settlor of the trust could not arise because as a result of the creation of the trust, the settlor got divested of the ownership of the amount of Rs. 30,00,000.
arguments.court_reasoning: The Government of India was aware of the above recitals in the trust deed at the time it entered into the agreement dated October 8, 1949 ... agreed to grant an exemption to the settlor

arguments.claim: Princess Niloufer, who was the beneficiary under the trust, could not transfer her beneficial interest in favour of the assessee.
arguments.court_reasoning: in view of section 58 of the Indian Trusts Act, 1882 ... the beneficiary if competent to contract, may transfer, his interest ... The present case is not covered by the proviso to that section.

arguments.claim: there is no equity about tax
arguments.court_reasoning: The dictum would not, however, be attracted when the question before the court as in the present case is the construction of an agreement and finding out the intention of the parties thereto

arguments.claim: the taxing authorities are not entitled, in determining whether a receipt is liable to be taxed, to ignore the legal character of the transaction which is the source of the receipt and to proceed on what they regard as the substance of the matter.
arguments.court_reasoning: The appellant, however, cannot derive assistance from it. The answer to the question ... depends upon the terms of agreement dated October 8, 1949.

arguments.claim: a fair reading of the agreement shows that the basic scheme of the agreement was that the payment of Rs. 1,00,000 under the agreement would be exempted from the payment of tax.

the Government of India declared and agreed unequivocally that the interest payable on the security of these presents shall be free from income-tax, super-tax and all other taxes ... There is nothing in the agreement that the Government wanted to show a special favour to Princess Niloufer personally
Reference to the settlor, trustees or beneficiaries in the above passage shows that the exemption was of a general and comprehensive nature and was not restricted to Princess Niloufer alone.

the beneficiary if competent to contract, may transfer, his interest, but subject to the law for the time being in force as to the circumstances and extent in and to which he may dispose of such interest. The present case is not covered by the proviso to that section.

The dictum would not, however, be attracted when the question before the court as in the present case is the construction of an agreement and finding out the intention of the parties thereto as manifested by its terms.

the taxing authority is entitled, and is indeed bound, to determine the true legal relation resulting from a transaction ... But the legal effect of a transaction cannot be displaced by probing into the substance of the transaction.

holdings.text: The assessee was entitled to exemption from tax in respect of the sum of Rs. 1,00,000 received by him from the trustees under the terms of the agreement dated October 8, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: After hearing the learned counsel for the parties at length, we are of the opinion that the contention of Mr. Gupte is well founded. We have set out above the material part of agreement dated October 8, 1949 which was entered into by the Government of India, the assessee and the three trustees,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fair reading of agreement shows basic scheme to exempt Rs. 1,00,000 payments from tax as quid pro quo for low 1% interest; exemption unequivocal and general to settlor, trustees, beneficiaries; not personal to Princess; Govt aware of trust and still granted to settlor.

holdings.text: A fair reading of the agreement shows that the basic scheme of the agreement was that the payment of Rs. 1,00,000 under the agreement would be exempted from the payment of tax.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Opening words of clause 4 unequivocally declare interest free from tax; no indication of special favour to Princess personally; consideration of low interest rate applies regardless of recipient; reference to settlor, trustees, beneficiaries shows general exemption.

holdings.text: Reference to the settlor, trustees or beneficiaries shows that the exemption was of a general and comprehensive nature and was not restricted to Princess Niloufer alone.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Clause agreeing not to assess/levy tax on settlor, trustees, or beneficiaries in respect of income/corpus; does not detract from dominant intention that Rs. 1,00,000 payment free of tax.

holdings.text: The assessee as settlor was entitled to exemption despite divesting ownership via trust, as Government agreed knowing recitals in trust deed.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Govt had copy of trust deed as annexure, knew of transfer to trustees, yet explicitly agreed to exempt settlor from tax on income/corpus; intention clear that settlor exempt in any case, including if beneficial interest devolves on him.

holdings.text: Princess Niloufer validly transferred her beneficial interest to the assessee under section 58 of the Indian Trusts Act, 1882.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Beneficiary competent to contract may transfer interest subject to law; proviso restricting married women during marriage inapplicable as transfer at time of dissolution.

holdings.text: The principle of 'no equity about a tax' does not apply to construction of an agreement granting tax exemption.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Dictum relevant for applying tax provisions strictly, but inapplicable where issue is interpreting parties' contractual intention on tax exemption.

holdings.text: The appellant cannot derive assistance from CIT v. B.M. Kharwar as the answer depends on the terms of the agreement dated October 8, 1949.
holdings.reasoning_summary: While taxing authorities bound to determine true legal relation, here legal effect explicitly governed by agreement terms which provide exemption; no device to unravel.

precedents.cited_proposition: Most of the questions during the assessment were decided in the light of this decision for the previous years' assessment of the same assessee

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Incometax Gujarat II v. B. M. Kharwar 1

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Incometax Gujarat II v. B. M. Kharwar 1 wherein it has been laid down that the taxing authorities are number entitled, in determining whether a receipt is liable to be taxed, to ignore the legal character of the transaction which is the source of the receipt and to proceed on what they regard as the substance of the matter.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax Gujarat II v. B. M. Kharwar
precedents.cited_proposition: Taxing authorities must determine the true legal relation from the transaction and cannot displace the legal effect by probing into substance; they can unravel devices but not ignore legal character
precedents.cited_holding: The taxing authority is entitled, and is indeed bound, to determine the true legal relation resulting from a transaction. If the parties have chosen to conceal by a device the legal relation, it is open to the taxing authorities to unravel the device
